snippet: Relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars find it hard to get information partly because of how G.M. defines victims, and the technology of “black boxes.”
abstract: Most upsetting to many relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars is the uncertainty and secrecy surrounding crashes; not only has GM twice adjusted the number of deaths it says are linked to an ignition switch defect, but it has also refused to disclose publicly the list of confirmed victims, leaving scores of grieving families playing a guessing game.

byline.original: By RACHEL ABRAMS and DANIELLE IVORY
byline.contributor: Rebecca R. Ruiz, Bill Vlasic and Kitty Bennett contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars find it hard to get information partly because of how G.M. defines victims, and the technology of “black boxes.”

headline.main: G.M. Secrecy on Crashes Adds to Families’ Pain
headline.print_headline: G.M. Secrecy on Crashes Adds to Families’ Pain
